title: 113_hr4084
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Community Gardening and Nutrition Act of 2014". The Congress acknowledges the benefits of community gardens, such as improving quality of life, providing nutritious food, and creating opportunities for recreation and economic development. Community gardens also help in cleaning up abandoned lots and donate fresh produce to local food pantries. Eating recommended amounts of vegetables and fruits can prevent deaths and save on medical costs. Health guidelines suggest more vegetables, legumes, and fruits, and less refined grains and fat. Studies show that community gardens promote healthy behaviors and improve dietary intakes, especially in children. The Community Garden Pilot Program is introduced. The Community Garden Pilot Program is introduced with initiatives to address health and nutrition in low-income communities, including creating new community gardens, recruiting local members, and transforming vacant spaces into garden plots. The Community Garden Pilot Program aims to increase access to healthy foods, promote community members' activity, expand anti-poverty efforts through nutrition education, and provide locally grown foods to the community. The Community Garden Pilot Program (SEC. 110) aims to increase access to healthy foods, promote community members' activity, expand anti-poverty efforts through nutrition education, and provide locally grown foods to the community. The Director will establish a Community Garden Pilot Program with a minimum of 40 projects, prioritizing volunteers with relevant experience, projects in diverse locations, and a mix of urban and rural projects. Authorization for funding is provided under section 501(a) of the Act. The table of contents in section 1(b) of the Act is amended to include $4,000,000 for fiscal year 2014 for section 110 of title I, remaining available until expended. SEC. 4. REPORT.

Within 90 days of completing the Community Garden Pilot Program, the Assistant Director must submit a report to Congress detailing project descriptions, results, analysis, and recommendations for the Program's continuation.
